fields.description: GUI-1558 is one example of a problem common throughout the code. We should tackle this problem throughout to avoid the same type of thing.
fields.summary: Ensure unicode strings are used in str.format() calls to avoid HTTP 500 errors with non-Latin characters

comments.body: [~scottb] this should be added to the known issues release notes.

[~scottb]: To clarify what we need to document for the 4.1 KI, the following (or similar wording) should be added to the release notes...

"Non-latin characters in resource names can trigger HTTP 500 errors on various pages.  Affected resources include snapshots, key pairs, security groups, scaling groups, and launch configurations".

See the linked tickets for more info.

[~kgill]/[~jloza]:

FYI here, AWS behavior here is to not support non-ASCII characters. This is what I got when I tested adding a name of a keypair on AWS Management Console with an ä : 

"Character sets beyond ASCII are not supported"

If you look at the EC2 API request CreateKeyPair (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/API_CreateKeyPair.html), the following limitation is mentioned:
{quote}
*KeyName*
A unique name for the key pair.

Constraints: Up to 255 ASCII characters

Type: String

Required: Yes
{quote}
This is also the same for ec2-create-keypair:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-CreateKeyPair.html

I tested this out and the following message was returned:
{code}
$ ec2-create-keypair test-cätz 
Client.InvalidParameterValue: Value (test-cätz) for parameter KeyName is invalid. Character sets beyond ASCII are not supported.
{code}

Currently, the User Console in 4.1 returns an "Internal Server Error".  In 4.0.2, it just hangs.  Maybe we can return an error message in a pop-up window?  I have attached the error seen on AWS to this ticket.  Let me know if there are any questions.

[~kgill]/[~jloza]/[~dkavanagh]:

I used the User Console against AWS, and I go the same "Internal Server Error" behavior.  Given that AWS doesn't access non-ASCII characters for keynames, should we allow this when interacting with Eucalyptus?

What started this was a non-latin character in a snapshot name (tag). We aren't saying keypairs should have non-latin characters. Clearly, keypairs are limited to ASCII characters and we should maintain that. We had another problem with keypairs that contained a "/", which is allowable but we weren't (GUI-1524)

[~dkavanagh], 

Ah, ok.  Thanks for the clarification.  I checked out the AWS docs regarding tagging (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/APIReference/API_Tag.html), and I see what you mean.  Thanks man.

I want to merge the PR, but we should have an issue to upgrade boto in EPEL assigned to @gholms which is a blocker for this one. QA won't be able to fully test till they can pull new boto (which they could do for testing) but we can't release 4.1.1 till that's complete and it takes a few weeks.
